body: What happens when you try to connect (connection refused, http error, no content, timeout, ...)? The http server can exit with an error, but there should be a panic in that case, with the accompanying logs and stuff.
Yeah, check for panic files in the config dir
I get timeouts @calmh. There are no panic files.

Are you running a recent version?
There was one old version with this bug.
The best way to debug this would probably be have a custom debug build, as I don't see how to work out what's happening otherwise.
Running the latest version v.10.8

Try this build (not tested):
http://build.syncthing.net/job/syncthing-branch/1314/

Should be quite verbose, but perhaps will help pin down the problem.
I've put that build online now. Are you aware that it shows much less information for the Shared folders in the webGUI?

That's the new design coming in the next version.
Only stuff which is `not default` is shown.
Also, make sure it does not get restarted when it fails, and make sure that the logs are redirected somewhere.

Will report back here tomorrow morning as that's normally when it will stop responding

EDIT: ps. the new layout for selecting devices a folder is shared with is much better!
sure.
Timeouts are weirder; then the server is obviously still there, but not processing requests...
Yes @calmh that's correct. As nodes can still connect and transfer files in between just can't connect to the webGUI until the process is restarted.

Oh, right, so the only thing the build will show is if it's still accepting connections after the given time, but that's about it.
I guess that's a place to start.

Actually, run this build once it's finished:
http://build.syncthing.net/job/syncthing-branch/1315/
That build is now running
make sure you capture the log output as it breaks ;)
It all logs into journalctl :-)
Also, when this happens, try curl:ing or just surfing to `http://localhost:8080/rest/ping` to see if _that_ responds or not.

I will do, I've just tried the WebGUI and it's still responding at the minute. I will try again this evening.

As this is a central server I've been accessing it remotely via its hostname, I will try setting up a tunnel and accessing via localhost as well when it happens.

Right weirdly enough this build hasn't reproduced the same behaviour yet, I thought it had but it only failed to connect once and the second time worked correctly and looking through the log the only thing obvious is this:

Nov 30 01:34:10 xxxx,xxx-dpe01.srv.**********.co.uk syncthing[22897]: [2GSRE] 2014/11/30 01:34:10.328364 tls.go:131: DEBUG: Got error while peeking EOF

I was using Google Chrome   41.0.2224.3 (Official Build) dev-m.

Right now though, everything is still operational and has been the longest time since trying Syncthing that the WebGUI has been accessible. I will try again tomorrow and report back.

> tls.go:131: DEBUG: Got error while peeking EOF

That means the client (i.e. browser) hung up on us before sending anything. Could be a cancelled request, or for that matter a bug on our side where we don't get any data for whatever reason, but the browser thinks it's sent and is waiting for a reply and in the end times out. In that case I'd suspect some sort of firewall or antivirus messing with us, but it's hard to say...

I doubt our firewall (pfSense) has blocked this as my IP is allowed through the webGUI port and my IP is also in a Snort pass list. I have noticed that pfSense's Snort package has been blocking newly updated IP Aliases but this doesn't apply to this request as my IP hasn't changed for quite some time (about a month) and I've checked the logs.

I believe it may be possible that Chrome is sending invalid requests as our firewall was previously blocking invalid SSL requests which I have since allowed

> #(ssp_ssl) Invalid Client HELLO after Server HELLO Detected
> suppress gen_id 137, sig_id 1

Is it possible that the WebGUI is receiving a HELLO after the server has sent it and then closing the connection?

The WebGUI is still fully operational with this build and I'm thinking of moving it over to v.10.9 and seeing how it goes.

So, we do some magic stuff here. We listen for whatever the client sends first - if it looks like a TLS ClientHello, we do TLS negotiation, otherwise we assume plain HTTP. The error you quoted above ("eof when peeking") is us looking for that first byte of data from the client to make this judgement, but the connection was closed.

In either protocol (TLS or HTTP), the client is supposed to "shoot first" and I think we'd log the error on the console if there is funny business with the TLS negotiation - at least I've seen such errors when testing, but I'm not 100% certain we always log them etc.
Right it's been several days now since using v.10.9 and these problems haven't reoccurred so it seems the behaviour before remains unexplained...
Ehem, `firewall` ehem.
